title: Monday, 28th November, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Morning

Quiet feel to things this morning -- post Thanksgiving in the US

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Just for a rest

PM11:02am

PM11:05am

Maybe mention Sports Direct straight up

Sports Direct International PLC (SPD:LSE): Last: 295.00, down 7.2 (-2.38%), High: 303.00, Low: 282.30, Volume: 970.19k
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Go on .....

PM11:05am

The Financial Reporting Council (FRC) has commenced investigations under the Accountancy Scheme and the Audit Enforcement Procedure in relation to the preparation, approval and audit of the financial statements of Sports Direct International plc (“Sports Direct”) for the 52 week period ended 24 April 2016. These decisions follow reports of an arrangement between Sports Direct and Barlin Delivery Limited which was not disclosed as a related party in the company’s financial statements.

PM11:05am

Barlin Delivery is owned by Ashley's elder brother

11:05 am
PM11:06am

This is the work of Mark Vandevelde

PM11:06am

Thumbs up

PM11:06am

https://www.ft.com...-a08a-c7ac04ef00aa

11:06 am
PM11:06am

He's updated this morning here: https://www.ft.com...-bfa3-6c7e1f015128

PM11:07am

Barlin Delivery is owned by John Ashley and has its registered office in a detached house in a Cleethorpes cul-de-sac, a small seaside resort on the Humber estuary in Lincolnshire. The company receives a share of the revenue from Sports Direct’s website orders that are dispatched overseas.

PM11:07am

Very very strange

11:08 am
PM11:08am

A page on the retailer’s website that explains Barlin’s role says the company “does not sell goods, but only delivers them”. Yet Barlin owns no trucks and employs no drivers. Instead it pays couriers such as DHL to collect parcels from a Sports Direct warehouse.

BE11:08am

............. It is, though as we've talked about previously, investors only seem concerned about Ashley's unorthodox management style when the shares go down.

BE11:09am

It's nearly 10 years since the float and we've had, what, three pushbacks against Ashley? All three correlate perfectly with the stock's lows.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

I'm not criticising the Financial Reporting Council here, to be clear. Because I wouldn't. It's just that, from the perspective of the money, bad governance only ever seems to be a unidirectional argument.

BE11:10am

(@LongandWrong: point me to the complaints in 2014.)

Back to the banks, though.

11:16 am
Royal Bank of Scotland Group PLC (RBS:LSE): Last: 196.40, down 5.1 (-2.53%), High: 201.50, Low: 195.40, Volume: 5.10m
CYBG PLC (CYBG:LSE): Last: 281.50, up 9.8 (+3.61%), High: 281.80, Low: 275.60, Volume: 491.80k
BE11:17am

I'll come to the stress tests in a moment, but first there's the neverending W&G story to get out of the way.

11:17 am
PM11:17am

That's become desperate

PM11:17am

The need to sell it, that is

BE11:17am

That's the feeling, yes. SunTel had an update on CYBG buying.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Gist is that CYBG has proposed not taking “some of W&G’s corporate bank, which includes its SME customers as well as some of its branches”

BE11:18am

Which'd make for a better deal for them, though it's hard to see what RBS gets out of it other than a sense of progress.

BE11:19am

Relatedly, Goldman pushing CYBG over the weekend.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

The argument is: "we're not assuming they buy W&G, but they probably will and it'll likely be making out like bandits. But we're not assuming that."

BE11:20am

On a standalone basis we see improving cost and capital efficiency as priced-in...
We believe CYBG’s strategy of loan growth, cost cuts and reducing capital requirements provides a credible path to higher returns and excess capital distribution. With CYBG at c.0.9x TBV for a c.12% 2020E ROTE (adjusted for excess capital), we see this as largely priced-in.

BE11:20am

...but see potential upside from value-accretive M&A
However, we do not believe the current price incorporates potential upside from value- accretive M&A. CYBG is in discussions regarding Williams & Glyn (W&G) and is open to strategically-aligned acquisitions more broadly. In our view, a number of opportunities for inorganic growth remain possible through in-market consolidation, and potential portfolio acquisitions.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

W&G scenario analysis: Capital treatment is key...
With CYBG in discussions over W&G, in this report we conduct a comprehensive scenario analysis, assessing the likely financial implications of any potential transaction for CYBG. Our scenario analysis estimates the sensitivity of both steady-state (FY21E) implied valuation and the required primary equity raise to the three key uncertainties involved in any transaction: purchase price, cost synergies, and additional capital add-ons.
From a financial perspective, capital treatment is key. CYBG’s IRB transition provides excess capital in 2019/20. Assuming W&G remains subject to IRB-treatment throughout, CYBG’s excess capital could fund a deal without the need for a significant equity raise. This scenario implies a meaningfully higher steady-state valuation range.

BE11:20am

...and we believe an alternative solution for W&G will be agreed in the near term
RBS is a forced seller, and we believe price is of lesser importance to achieving an “assured” exit (a critical hurdle for capital return). RBS is actively exploring alternatives regarding W&G, and we believe a solution could be agreed in the near term with a trade sale the most likely option.

BE11:20am

Our price target incorporates value-accretive M&A potential; we upgrade to Buy
We adjust our estimates by -1% to +18% to reflect a more supportive rate environment, a more muted impact from front-book mortgage spreads as well as changes to costs and below the line items.
We incorporate the potential for value-accretive M&A into our price target, reflecting CYBG’s openness to strategically-aligned acquisitions. Our valuation adjustment for M&A takes account of a wider range of potential inorganic opportunities and does not relate to any specific transaction. In our view, a number of opportunities for inorganic growth remain possible through in-market consolidation, and potential portfolio acquisitions. Our M&A adjustment (45p) relates only to potential operating cost synergies, and is based on the 20% synergies targeted in relation to Sabadell’s acquisition of TSB (the most recent and relevant comparable transaction in UK banks). This, combined with the impact of our estimate changes, causes our 12-month ROTE/COE-based price target to increase to 330p (from 250p). We also roll forward our price target (now based on FY18E and FY19E returns, previously FY17E and FY18E). Consequently with 20% potential upside, we upgrade the shares to Buy from Neutral.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

See? They're not assuming a purchase of W&G, but the upgrade's on "value accretive M&A" and W&G is the only plausible target really.

PM11:21am

hehe

PM11:21am

It's had the desired effect tho

11:22 am
PM11:22am

When are the stress test results?

PM11:22am

11:22 am

Lloyds the most fragile, it's widely agreed.

Lloyds Banking Group plc (LLOY:LSE): Last: 57.64, down 1.13 (-1.92%), High: 58.55, Low: 57.52, Volume: 68.95m
BE11:23am

I have Goldman on this too, if you like.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Our stress test assumptions are broadly consistent with the 4.5 pp shock to UK unemployment outlined in the BoE’s 2016 stress test
assumptions. Our analysis finds that the sector appears resilient to ‘tail risks’ given strong starting capital ratios: no banks have a
CET1 ratio materially below 8.0% or a leverage ratio below 3.0% under our ‘Extreme’ scenario. The ability to adjust dividend payouts
further enhances this position. Within this strong performance, under our ‘Extreme’ scenario, Lloyds is lowest among the large-cap
banks , while a group of the ‘Challengers’ (Shawbrook, Virgin Money and CYBG) are among the weakest performers but are,
however, not part of the BoE’s stress test.

BE11:24am

Our analysis studies first-order impacts of a worsening UK macroeconomic environment. It is therefore subject to a number of limitations: (1) it is based chiefly on differences in risk characteristics between different loan types, with only limited adjustments for idiosyncratic differences in the risk profile of banks’ individual exposures; (2) it ignores second-order impacts on other economies; and (3) it ignores any potential impact from liquidity risk, market risk and conduct risk.

BE11:25am

From our perspective, the results of our
stress-test analysis reveal a number of important outcomes:
 Sector appears resilient to ‘tail risks’ – Banks’ high starting regulatory capital positions provide a buffer against higher
impairments in our ‘Extreme’ scenario. None of the subject banks has a CET1 ratio materially below 8.0% or a leverage ratio
below 3.0% in our initial analytical framework (which makes no adjustment to capital distributions).

 Dividend flexibility provides further support –Only one bank (CYBG) has a CET1 ratio below 9.0% in 2018E under our ‘Extreme’ scenario excluding dividends paid during 2017-18E. In this case we note that once the group’s IRB transition is taken
into account, this number would be materially north of 10%.

 Lloyds most exposed among the large-cap UK banks... – Among the large-cap banks, Lloyds is the lowest in terms of CET1
under our ‘Extreme’ scenario, which we view as mostly a function of (i) the group’s focus on UK retail and commercial banking,
(ii) the adverse performance of ‘legacy’ assets under stress, and (iii) the group’s larger exposure to unsecured retail.

 ...with the ‘Challengers’ also significantly impacted – in our ‘Extreme’ scenario, the ‘Challengers’ (chiefly Virgin Money,
Shawbrook and CYBG) are among the weakest banks in terms of CET1 ratios (and also the leverage ratio for Virgin). This is unsurprising to us given their focus on the UK and the fact that their (typically) higher cost of funds encourages them to focus on higher-yielding segments. While the ultimate determination of any potential losses remains highly uncertain, smaller banks do have limited exposure either outside of the UK or to market risk.

11:25 am

11:30 am

Here's some Liberum

PM11:31am

Aberdeen has done a good job of managing expectations. Adj. PBT and EPS beat consensus by c.7%, aided by the benefit of strong FX and positive market performance. The outlook statement refers to multiple challenges and the current quarter will be a difficult one for net flows. Our forecasts are 10% below consensus in FY17 and given this morning's numbers, we expect a meeting in the middle. Aberdeen currently trades on 15x FY17 P/E and yields 6.8% based on our FY17 dividend forecast.

PM11:31am

With regard to net flows in the higher margin equities business, Aberdeen notes that the level of equities outflows declined steadily throughout the year, although the company still expects "some fluctuation from quarter to quarter". The company indicates that Q1/FY17 will see outflows from "two lower margin, but large blocks of AUM". We expect net outflows of £19.2B for the whole of FY17.
Aberdeen identifies that the asset management sector is facing three head winds: "fee pressure, increased investment in technology and regulatory capital requirements." With regard to mitigating these, Aberdeen indicates that it will continue to seek further cost efficiencies beyond the £70 million which it remains "on track" to achieve by March 2017.
Aberdeen does not expect either its non-UK or UK businesses to be "affected in a substantive way" by the result UK referendum, although the company notes that there "may be regulatory and/or legal changes in the longer term."

11:31 am
BE11:31am

PM11:01am

PM11:33am

PM11:33am

is there an Exane downgrade around?

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Exane downgrade.

BE11:33am

We downgrade the stock to Neutral as the continued sluggish fund performance, impacting the outlook for performance fees and fund flows, prompts material downgrades to our earnings expectations, while the amount of surplus capital for materially accretive deals is limited. Man Group looks optically cheap on 10x EV/NOPAT 17e, but 40% of 17e earnings are from performance fees.

BE11:34am

11:34 am
PM11:34am

(We obviously have on giong tech problems -- do try refreshing, clearing caches, etc)

BE11:35am

..... Anyway, common theme of AHL's black box not really working.

BE11:35am

We reduce our EPS estimates by 15% for FY16e and 27% for FY17e. This is from a combination of lower performance fees (AHL funds ex. Evolution all down YTD), negative performance contribution in Q4, softer Q4 flow expectations and the stronger USD.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We estimate that AHL Diversified is down -8.1% YTD, AHL Alpha -3.5% YTD and AHL Dimension - 3.9% YTD. While the relative performance (2nd quartile) is still decent, this is a bleaker picture than at the HY results when the same funds were up +5.4%, +0.6% and +0.1% respectively. We now estimate that the weighted average distance from high water mark to be around 10%.

BE11:36am

Down 8% YTD! That's terrible!

BE11:36am

As in, chimp-with-a-pin terrible.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

While we continue to see Aalto as a well-structured deal, the scale of the business means a muted near term impact (+1% to FY17E EPS). At the same time, accounting for the PV of deferred consideration alongside the ongoing buyback programme means a more material reduction in surplus capital from $470m to $300m (~12% of market cap). We see this as lowering the near-term upside risk to the shares from materially accretive M&A.

BE11:37am

We see risks on flows at GLG alternative as funds remain 3rd/4th quartile. Management fee margins also seem to remain under pressure (Och Ziff, Tudor, Caxton and Brevan Howard have all been cited in the press as cutting management fees this year).

BE11:37am

And that's that.

One of those disruptive small suppliers, blaming a "swift and significant" increase in wholesale prices.

BE11:40am

Positive first because price-aggressive competitors dying is always positive, but also it makes any government moves to encourage competition a wee bit more difficult.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Here's Citi ... Or will be in a moment.

BE11:41am

..,,,,,,,,,,,,,.... Quite a long moment.

BE11:41am

The initial reaction to this could be that a loss of competitor would be good for the Big 6 players (including Centrica and SSE), and that this would flag the risks surrounding a small supplier compared to its larger counterpart, especially in the context of an ongoing review of the supply companies by the government. While we believe these arguments do have certain merits, we also believe it will add another dimension to be considered by the government as part of its ongoing review – that a truly competitive retail energy market appears difficult to achieve, with smaller suppliers unable to compete with the Big 6 to cope with volatility by means of balance sheet and hedging (with no physical assets). This begs the question if the retail energy market should be competitive at all? If so, can Ofgem and the politicians live with an unlevel playing field? Given the industry have been under scrutiny from Ofgem and then the CMA over the last c.8 years, it is fair to conclude that a truly competitive market is difficult to achieve, especially when two thirds of customers remain on standard variable tariffs (are inclined not to switch), and that neither Ofgem nor the politicians are happy with the current status quo.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

In our view, the current government wants to be seen to be tackling these issues and we continue to see risks of further political intervention in the energy retail market (see Centrica PLC (CNA.L): Playing defense). We also continue to see any restructuring to target the lack of churn for the standard variable customers and expect long-term margins to be eroded to a more modest 3%. Even in the case that the government decides not to intervene, we believe it’s only a matter of time when the sector will come under renewed scrutiny. We continue to rate Centrica as Sell, PT of 175p and SSE as Neutral, PT of 1443p.

Ladbrokes Coral Group PLC (LCL:LSE): Last: 122.40, down 3.2 (-2.55%), High: 125.40, Low: 122.30, Volume: 977.71k
BE11:46am

(Why did they change their ticker from LAD? That's going to irritate me for another 18 months or so at least.)

BE11:46am

So, no response to this Mail on Sunday story about looking at Tabcorp

11:46 am
BE11:47am

Suggesting it's early stage at most. Perhaps very early stage.

BE11:47am

Mail says cash and scrip bid possible. Though logic would dictate more scrip than cash, as Ladbrokes really doesn't have any cash.

BE11:48am

Also has a load of regulatory problems (FOBTs etc) and a triennial review incoming.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

And buying in Australia, where Ladbrokes has a tiny but growing business, doesn't seem to do an awful lot other than provide scale.

BE11:49am

Certainly very little in the way of cost savings.

BE11:49am

Deutsche doesn't fancy the idea.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

While we believe there may be some strategic merit in Ladbrokes Coral looking at a potential merger with Tabcorp, we believe the challenges would include Ladbrokes’ recent merger with Gala Coral, the size of the potential transaction (A$4.9bn), relative trading multiples, convincing Tabcorp shareholders to accept Ladbrokes Coral scrip ahead of potential regulatory risks, and the relatively small amount of potential synergies.

BE11:49am

Ladbrokes currently has a relatively small wagering business in Australia with LTM revenue of $128m and EBIT of $4m, and the company has previously stated its intention to increase its presence in Australia. A merger with Tabcorp would fit with this strategy as well as increasing the company’s exposure to regulated markets, increasing its scale, and diversifying its geographic coverage, however, the potential synergies would be limited.

BE11:50am

A potential merger with Tabcorp would also be a sizeable transaction with the current enterprise valuation of Ladbrokes Coral (A$5.6bn) just 14% higher than that of Tabcorp (A$4.9bn). Given Ladbrokes’ current net leverage of 2.2x, a sizeable scrip component would be required and it may be difficult to convince Tabcorp shareholders to accept Ladbrokes scrip, particularly ahead of the UK Government’s Triennial Review into stakes and prizes on gaming machines.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

Also notes that Ladbrokes trades at a discount to Tabcorp. 12 times vs 20 times.

BE11:51am

Back to Deutsche.

BE11:51am

The main complication is the current Triennial Review into stakes and prizes on UK gaming machines, with submissions to Government due by early December and no set timetable for a Government response. With c80% of current EBITDA derived from its retail business and c50% of that from gaming machines, Ladbrokes Coral faces some short term earnings uncertainty as reflected in the recent negative share price performance. That uncertainty might create difficulty in valuing the paper element of any offer by Ladbrokes Coral.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

.......... So, yeah. Looks unlikely.

PM11:51am

BE11:32am

Aberdeen reported FY16 results slightly better than expected with underlying FY16 operating profits of £328m, 3% ahead of the £319m we were forecasting and -36% yoy. Outflows continuing in Qtr to Sep at -£7.2bn, taking FY total to -£32.8bn, which was in line with our forecasts but quality of mix is better with milder outflows out of Equities. Management do warn of 2 large but unquantified lower margin Institutional mandate redemptions so far in qtr to Dec. FY16 total revenues of £1,007m were down -15% yoy and operating expenses of £679m were flattish yoy, causing strong declines in op. profit margin yoy to 32.6% from 42.7% FY15. To protect/cause op. margin to recover in FY17 management has previously projected £70m of cost saves and details that only £28m of these have been realised so far in 2016 and run-rate at year-end is at £50m. Qtr to Sep outflows of -£7.2bn is in line with our forecast but mix is better, in particular only -£0.9bn out of equities of which GEM is +£0.6bn (although the suspicion may be this could reverse in 2017). End Sep AUM £312bn 3% higher than our forecast of £304bn, due to higher market movements/FX. At bottom line underlying FY16 diluted EPS of 20.7p was 7% higher than Barclays forecast of 19.2p mainly due to the recording of £23m of investment gains. DPS was as expected unchanged yoy at 19.5p and only ~1.06x covered. Management outlook appears pretty neutral. Share has been strongly sold off since the start of Oct (-17% vs FTSE Allshare -2%) on the back of weaker sentiment towards EM. It is trading at 13.3x calendar 2017E PE.
